awd_titl_txt: SBE: TTP Option: Medium: Data-Driven Cyber Vulnerability Maintenance
awd_abstract_narration:
Researchers have found that over 90% of successful cyber attacks exploit vulnerabilities that could have been fixed with available patches. Vulnerabilities can be weak passwords or software with bugs on personal computers, mobile devices, or printers. Yet, decision-making about manually applying patches is difficult. First, a substantial fraction of vulnerabilities are fixed each month by automatic patching. Second, applying patches can have side-effects, making software unusable. Third, organizations have limited abilities to estimate the profit from applying patches. 

This research generates optimized policies that specify which patches should be applied to which hosts. It does this by creating models of related costs that are based on data. The methods include a novel type of error estimation procedure which addresses the fact that data is limited, particularly in relation to the costs of actions that have rarely been applied. The associated mathematics extends a general decision tool called Markov decision processes to address uncertainty from limited data. This extension is achieved by solving open, fundamental mathematical problems. 

There are multiple real world applications planned in the transition to practice. The major partner is The Ohio State University which agrees to share monthly data on tens of thousands of computers and teams with the PIs for policy improvement. In addition to tuning individual host vulnerability-related policies, the PIs address password updating and network vulnerability policies.

por.por_cntn:
Vulnerabilities have causes including program bugs, out-of-date encryption methods, and/or weak passwords. They are present on PC, laptops, servers, printers, and many other devices in the Internet Of Things (IOT). Some software vendors are becoming more careful and producing fewer vulnerabilities but many others are creating software and hardware with high or critical vulnerabilities and failing to issue patches promptly. Many vulnerabilities are identified and then made public. Sometimes patches for these vulnerabilities are created and publicized by the associated vendors or others. Sometimes exploits are created or made public to offer intrusion or compromise possibilities for hackers.

The increasing reality is that the costs are too high to even attempt to patch all vulnerabilities. Also, organizations know about only a small fraction of their vulnerabilities through scanning. Many hosts are turned off or permissions are not granted during the scans, i.e., they are “dark hosts” with unknown vulnerabilities. Further, organizations rarely scan their non-fixed IP address hosts which are occupying an increasingly large portion of the attack surfaces.

The major practical findings were:

1.     Patching most Windows hosts high vulnerabilities is not cost effective based on our large dataset, unless perhaps if the hosts have very sensitive data on them. Microsoft has active auto-patching methods and the exploit rates during our time period are too low to merit the costs.

2.     Patching even medium Linux vulnerabilities can be costs effective, particularly for out-ward facing systems. The warnings or incidents experienced on these hosts carry sufficient direct costs to pay for the patching activities. Linux systems seem to have aging problems and may be less well maintained.

3.     There are many “dark host” vulnerabilities, i.e., vulnerabilities on hosts that are not present in the scans because they were turned off during the scans or permissions were not given. Addressing these is critical and prediction methods extending ones in our work can help. We have methods useful for predicting dark host vulnerabilities within our publications and further methods are being generated in continuing research.

4.     Feel free to visit http://www.blying.com/id13.html to obtain a limited amount of de-identified cyber vulnerability data. Such data is useful for predicting dark host vulnerabilities and for prioritizing vulnerabilities, particularly when combined with IDS warning and/or incident data.

5.     Cyber security in practice is quite bureaucratic, with many set piece activities. There is a need for quality engineering (including lean six sigma), reliability engineering, and operations research techniques. With these techniques, the systems can be studied to identify assignable causes that management would like to know about. We have some special charting methods for this. Also, prioritization can occur by developing data-driven control systems. We also developed methods for this purpose.

The major theoretical findings include:

1.     For autonomous control situations with limited data availability, the finite scenario model-based “fast” Bayesian Reinforcement Learning techniques offer many advantages. Learning occurs in fewer steps than for the alternative that we tested. Also, the methods are optimal in every step, not merely long-term optimal. These methods are being incorporated to create (hopefully) quite controllable but smart autonomous robots. Also, these methods can experiment to derive the most cost effective maintenance recommendations.

2.     For system monitoring, we have proposed MCRAD control charts which offer relatively desirable trade-offs between “run lengths” or sensitivity and specificity. The proposed charts have many possible applications and are based on the residuals from time series models.

3.     We developed desirable data-driven methods to balance between the costs of too short password renewal periods (user aggravation costs) and too longer periods (greater possibilities for compromise).

Modified by: Theodore T Allen
